Description.val:
The Family of Heavy Tactical Vehicles (FHTV) is designed for cross-country military missions to transport ammunition, petroleum, oils and lubricants, unit resupply, and other missions throughout the tactical environment to support modern and highly mobile combat units.  Systems include the Heavy Expanded Mobility Tactical Truck (HEMTT) and the Palletized Load System (PLS) which is currently in sustained production.  The HEMTT A4 and PLS A1 incorporate the Long Term Protection Strategy (LTPS) "B-Kit" Ready cab, a modern power train, independent front suspension, Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) and traction control, updated electrical system and climate control.  Both trucks utilize the companion PLS-trailer (A1) with Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE), and Enhanced Container Handling Units (E-CHU).  The HEMTT Light Equipment Transporter (LET) tractor is the primary recovery vehicle for the Modular Catastrophic Recovery System (MCRS) which is designed to recover catastrophically damaged Stryker's and Mine-Resistant Ambush-Protected (MRAP) vehicles.  The Heavy Equipment Transporter System (HETS) comprised of a tractor and trailer is also included in this family of vehicles.

The Heavy Equipment Transport System (HETS) is an effort to meet highway transportability requirements of the M1A2 Abrams Main Battle Tank in the United States Army Europe (USAREUR) Area of Operation (AOR).  The currently fielded and combat laded M1A2 SEPv2 exceeds the payload rating of the currently fielded HETS.  Additionally, axle weight standards in Europe are unable to be met by the current system.  therefore, the M1A2 is unable to be transported legally in the USAREUR AOR.  HETS provides a material solution to this problem by sourcing a platform to meet both the payload and permit-ability requirements to transport the M1A2.  This includes a target payload rating of approximately 75 (tons) while keeping individual axle weights below 11.5 metric tons (11,500 kg).  The HETS fleet is an essential combat enabler in moving the M1A2 across roads in USAEUR AOR.  This program produces a solution that ensures it can be transported safely and legally.

The M1076 trailer is used in conjunction with the PLS truck (M1074, and 1075 variants) as well as the HEMTT Load Handling System (LHS) M1120 variant.  It accommodates a demountable cargo bed capable of hauling up to 16.5 tons of cargo/payload.

The MCRS is designed to significantly enhance the Commander's ability to recover large wheeled vehicle platforms in several off-road conditions either in lift/tow or transport mode.  MCRS is comprised of the Prime mover (M983A4 LET), Fifth Wheel Towing Recovery Device (FWTRD), and the Tilt Deck Recovery Trailer (TDRT).  This program is not a new start.

The Army Acquisition Objective (AAO) for PLS Trailer (PLST-D08900) is 17,155, Modular Catastrophic Recovery System (MCRS-D12389) is 161, Container Handling Unit (ECHU-D16101) IS 3,887, and Heavy Equipment Transporter System (HETS) Excursion is 152.

Justification.val:
FY 2018 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $39.338 million supports a quantity of 324 M1076 Palletized Load System (PLS) trailers.  PLS trailers will fill Active Army and Army National Guard components requirements in support of Stryker and Modular Brigade Combat Teams (BCT) activations, Patriot Units, and Combat Engineers.

FY 2018 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $4.920 million supports a quantity of 15 Modular Catastrophic Recovery System (MCRS).  The MCRS will fill Active Army requirements to recover catastrophically damaged Stryker's and Mine-Resistant Ambush-Protected (MRAP) vehicles.

FY 2018 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $37.398 million supports a quantity of 20 Heavy Equipment Transporter System (HETS).   HETS will fill Active Army requirements to transport the M1A2 Abrams Main Battle Tank in the United States Army Europe (USAREUR) Area of Operation (AOR).

FY 2018 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $24.562 million supports a quantity of 258 M1076 PLS trailers and $1.312 million procures 4 MCRS for the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI).  Procurement is necessary to outfit the Pre-Positioned equipment set.  There is no excess inventory or viable substitute available to support the ERI requirement.

System Engineering/Program Management (SEPM) includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other Government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce.

In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks.val: Unit costs are determined by range pricing at ceiling amount for each Ordering Year (OY) and reconciled after the delivery order (DO) is completed.

Name.val: TRUCK CARGO TAC 8X8: HVY EXPANDED MOB W/LHS

OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks.val: Unit costs are determined by range pricing at ceiling amount for each Ordering Year (OY) and reconciled after the delivery order (DO) is completed.

OverallDeliveryScheduleRemarks.val: Currently no contractor has been selected.  The Production Rates are based on market research.  These figures will be updated once a contractor has been selected.
